rules.text: Political discussion and debate is fine, arguing like children is fine if you really want, but keep it mostly civil and do not attack someone personally.
Interacting with the community is highly recommended, but lurkers are welcome too if that's your thing.
If you encounter issues with any of our server's and or members. Please let an admin or moderator know!
Treat others how you would like to be treated
Do not advertise without permission and absolutely no link building campaign accounts.  Accounts for knock-off imitation products, gambling, and cock fighting will be promptly blocked.
Staff and moderators decisions are authoritative and final, but we're still humans; feel free to open a dialogue to ask about our decisions.
Community members are free to express themselves openly and give constructive criticism and feedback
No exposed genitalia (penis, vagina) in your profile image or profile banner.  Full nudity is allowed within posts when a Content Warning (NSFW/nudity/etc) is applied to inform folks of the content.

Valid and reachable email is required, no temporary email accounts, sorry.  We don't sell your emails or sign you up for bullshit, but we _do_ need to be able to reach you should there be an issue with your account.
No selling drugs, (legal or illegal), on the platform.
Due to an ongoing attack against the network, we have temporally changed registrations to require moderator approval.

records.text: So I recently got thinking about #Inflation and the direct link with salary incomes.Having entering the job force around 2002 and into the IT industry around 2006, in my mind $100k would have been a REALLY good paying job back then, and that mindset has kind of stuck.  "6-figure" job and all that.Now if hypothetically one had a $60k job back then, one could think that a $120k job _now_ would be a major upgrade in salary and purchasing ability, as simple math states that 120 is double of 60.However, would my understanding be correct to think instead that a $120k job _now_ would be a $75k job back then?  If so that would only be a 25% upgrade in income, (which is still net positive, but...)#Financial

records.text: How #Dev and #QA works at my work:Developer branches off, does the work, commits dev branch. (nothing too unusual thus far)  Developer creates merge request in Gitlab.At this stage, it should be noted that Gitlab has support for 1) automatic build automation and verification and 2) assignment for merge requests to other developers to approve.Are either of those used?  NOPE!  Original developer messages a lead on Teams with a link to the merge request.  Lead cherry picks branch or completes merge and manually deploys to QA.Original developer then has to pre-QA that the work is ready to be QA'd in the correct environment, reassigns the ticket to the QA lead, and messages the QA lead on Teams that the issue is ready for testing.QA lead inevitably asks if it's working as expected in test, (which is odd because I would expect that's the responsibility of QA).QA will then message the original developer on Teams that the work is approved, who then original dev needs to message the Lead on Teams that the work is ready for prod.  This is another manual merge and a manual deployment on production._sigh_..... corporate efficiency at its finest.  Even worse from a company that has "Workflow Automation" as one of our product offerings. :/

records.text: So I recently got thinking about #Inflation and the direct link with salary incomes.Having entering the job force around 2002 and into the IT industry around 2006, in my mind $100k would have been a REALLY good paying job back then, and that mindset has kind of stuck.  "6-figure" job and all that.Now if hypothetically one had a $60k job back then, one could think that a $120k job _now_ would be a major upgrade in salary and purchasing ability, as simple math states that 120 is double of 60.However, would my understanding be correct to think instead that a $120k job _now_ would be a $75k job back then?  If so that would only be a 25% upgrade in income, (which is still net positive, but...)#Financial

records.text: How #Dev and #QA works at my work:Developer branches off, does the work, commits dev branch. (nothing too unusual thus far)  Developer creates merge request in Gitlab.At this stage, it should be noted that Gitlab has support for 1) automatic build automation and verification and 2) assignment for merge requests to other developers to approve.Are either of those used?  NOPE!  Original developer messages a lead on Teams with a link to the merge request.  Lead cherry picks branch or completes merge and manually deploys to QA.Original developer then has to pre-QA that the work is ready to be QA'd in the correct environment, reassigns the ticket to the QA lead, and messages the QA lead on Teams that the issue is ready for testing.QA lead inevitably asks if it's working as expected in test, (which is odd because I would expect that's the responsibility of QA).QA will then message the original developer on Teams that the work is approved, who then original dev needs to message the Lead on Teams that the work is ready for prod.  This is another manual merge and a manual deployment on production._sigh_..... corporate efficiency at its finest.  Even worse from a company that has "Workflow Automation" as one of our product offerings. :/

records.text: So I recently got thinking about #Inflation and the direct link with salary incomes.Having entering the job force around 2002 and into the IT industry around 2006, in my mind $100k would have been a REALLY good paying job back then, and that mindset has kind of stuck.  "6-figure" job and all that.Now if hypothetically one had a $60k job back then, one could think that a $120k job _now_ would be a major upgrade in salary and purchasing ability, as simple math states that 120 is double of 60.However, would my understanding be correct to think instead that a $120k job _now_ would be a $75k job back then?  If so that would only be a 25% upgrade in income, (which is still net positive, but...)#Financial

records.text: How #Dev and #QA works at my work:Developer branches off, does the work, commits dev branch. (nothing too unusual thus far)  Developer creates merge request in Gitlab.At this stage, it should be noted that Gitlab has support for 1) automatic build automation and verification and 2) assignment for merge requests to other developers to approve.Are either of those used?  NOPE!  Original developer messages a lead on Teams with a link to the merge request.  Lead cherry picks branch or completes merge and manually deploys to QA.Original developer then has to pre-QA that the work is ready to be QA'd in the correct environment, reassigns the ticket to the QA lead, and messages the QA lead on Teams that the issue is ready for testing.QA lead inevitably asks if it's working as expected in test, (which is odd because I would expect that's the responsibility of QA).QA will then message the original developer on Teams that the work is approved, who then original dev needs to message the Lead on Teams that the work is ready for prod.  This is another manual merge and a manual deployment on production._sigh_..... corporate efficiency at its finest.  Even worse from a company that has "Workflow Automation" as one of our product offerings. :/

records.text: Dear #Google / #Android;I got a new phone and am installing apps to get this new device setup with all the network management utilities I need on a day to day basis.Stop giving me "Sponsored" suggestions.I'm NEVER going to install a sponsored app.  I am willing to put money that 100% of the "sponsored" apps are ad-riddled malware infected pieces of garbage, and thus have ABSOLUTELY no desire to EVER install any of them.Ad block doesn't remove them; if I keep seeing them, I'm going to have to disable the Play store and exclusively use F-Droid.

records.text: Hmmm, my order from #IFixIt came in and I got the battery and charging port swapped on the phone.  It now vibrates when I hit the power button, but that's about it :/I may need to disassemble it again and just double check everything.  It's only a 4 year old device, so I really don't want to have to replace it, but fear it may have issues on the mainboard which exceed my capability to repair.That said though, I was really impressed with the quality of the parts and tools provided by ifixit.  They even included stickers!#RightToRepair
